components.renderables

Class MeshComponent

  • java.lang.Object
    • core.Component
      • components.renderables.MeshComponent
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Invalidatable

    public class MeshComponent
extends Component
    Encapsulates a Mesh and a Material. Renderers can render this Component.
    See Also:
    Mesh, Material, Renderer

      • getOriginalFurthestVertexDistance

        public float getOriginalFurthestVertexDistance()
        Returns the distance between the origin and the Mesh's furthest vertex. This value is not depends on the GameObject's scale (object space), so if you scale the GameObject, this method gives you wrong value. If you want to get the scaled value of the furthest vertex distance (what is depends on the GameObject's scale), use the getRealFurthestVertexDistance method.
        Returns:
        furthest vertex distance
        See Also:
        getRealFurthestVertexDistance(), Transform.getAbsoluteScale()

      • getRealFurthestVertexDistance

        public float getRealFurthestVertexDistance()
        Returns the distance between the origin and the Mesh's furthest vertex. This value depends on the GameObject's scale (world space), so even if you scale the GameObject, this method gives you the right value. If you want to get the original value of the furthest vertex distance (what is not depends on the GameObject's scale), use the getOriginalFurthestVertexDistance method.
        Note that if this Component doesn't assigned to a GameObject (if getGameObject returns null), this method returns the original furthest vertex distance.
        Returns:
        furthest vertex distance
        See Also:
        getOriginalFurthestVertexDistance(), Transform.getAbsoluteScale(), Component.getGameObject()

      • getOriginalAabbMin

        @NotNull
 @ReadOnly
public org.joml.Vector3f getOriginalAabbMin()
        Returns the axis alligned bounding box's minimum x, y and z values. This value is not depends on the GameObject's position, rotation and scale (object space), so if you move, rotate or scale the GameObject, this method gives you wrong value. If you want to get the moved, rotated and scaled value of the AABB min, use the getRealAabbMin method.
        Returns:
        the axis alligned bounding box's minimum x, y and z values
        See Also:
        getRealAabbMin(), Transform.getAbsoluteScale(), Transform.getAbsolutePosition()

      • getRealAabbMin

        @NotNull
 @ReadOnly
public org.joml.Vector3f getRealAabbMin()
        Returns the axis alligned bounding box's minimum x, y and z values. This value depends on the GameObject's position, rotation and scale (world space), so even if you move, rotate or scale the GameObject, this method gives you the right values. If you want to get the original value of the AABB min (what is not depends on the GameObject's position, rotation and scale), use the getOriginalAabbMin method.
        Note that if this Component doesn't assigned to a GameObject (if getGameObject returns null), this method returns the original AABB min.
        Returns:
        the axis alligned bounding box's minimum x, y and z values
        See Also:
        getOriginalAabbMin(), Transform.getAbsoluteScale(), Transform.getAbsolutePosition(), Component.getGameObject()

      • getOriginalAabbMax

        @NotNull
 @ReadOnly
public org.joml.Vector3f getOriginalAabbMax()
        Returns the axis alligned bounding box's maximum x, y and z values. This value is not depends on the GameObject's position, rotation and scale (object space), so if you move, rotate or scale the GameObject, this method gives you wrong value. If you want to get the moved, rotated and scaled value of the AABB max, use the getRealAabbMax method.
        Returns:
        the axis alligned bounding box's maximum x, y and z values
        See Also:
        getRealAabbMax(), Transform.getAbsoluteScale(), Transform.getAbsolutePosition()

      • getRealAabbMax

        @NotNull
 @ReadOnly
public org.joml.Vector3f getRealAabbMax()
        Returns the axis alligned bounding box's maximum x, y and z values. This value depends on the GameObject's position, rotation and scale (world space), so even if you move, rotate or scale the GameObject, this method gives you the right values. If you want to get the original value of the AABB max (what is not depends on the GameObject's position, rotation and scale), use the getOriginalAabbMax method.
        Note that if this Component doesn't assigned to a GameObject (if getGameObject returns null), this method returns the original AABB max.
        Returns:
        the axis alligned bounding box's maximum x, y and z values
        See Also:
        getOriginalAabbMax(), Transform.getAbsoluteScale(), Transform.getAbsolutePosition(), Component.getGameObject()
